reg:regulation.reg:title: Islands Trust Natural Area Protection Tax Exemption Regulation
reg:regulation.reg:amsincluded: [includes amendments up to B.C. Reg. 117/2018, June 15, 2018]

bcl:definition.bcl:text: Act means the Islands Trust Act;
protection exemption means a tax exemption under Part 7.1 [Natural Area Protection Tax Exemptions] of the Act;

sensitive ecosystems inventory means the Sensitive Ecosystems Inventory: East Vancouver Island and Gulf Islands, 1993-1997, Volume 1: Methodology, Ecological Descriptions and Results, Technical Report Series No. 320, Canadian Wildlife Service, Pacific and Yukon Region, British Columbia, 1998.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In addition, the definitions in section 49.1 of the Act apply to this regulation.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The following are prescribed as natural values and amenities for purposes of Part 7.1 [Natural Area Protection Tax Exemptions] of the Act:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: areas that are relatively undisturbed by human activity and are good examples of one or more of the ecosystems described in the Schedule to this regulation;
areas that are relatively undisturbed by human activity and are key habitat for rare native plant species or plant communities;
areas that are critical habitat for native animal species in relation to breeding, rearing, feeding or staging;

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: rare glacial erosion or deposition features, or
shoreline deposition features, including tombolos, spits and hooks;
heritage orchards, being orchards that were planted before the end of the First World War;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: social or recreational features that are

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: walking or hiking trails that provide public access through natural areas,
outstanding viewpoints that are accessible to the public,

bcl:clause.bcl:text: are distinctive, historic, or relatively undisturbed by human activity, and
have a high degree of visibility from a place accessible to the public, or

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: land that provides public access to property that

bcl:clause.bcl:text: is subject to a protection exemption, or
is a park or other land to which the public has access for a purpose related to the enjoyment and appreciation of ecosystems and natural areas.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A protection exemption is an exemption from tax on the land that is subject to the protection covenant to the extent determined as follows:

oasis:entry.oasis:line: assessed value = the assessed value of the land that is subject to the protection covenant.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The amount referred to in section 49.7 (2) (a) (i) [base recapture amount] of the Act is to be determined as follows:

oasis:line.in:em: base recapture amount = (final year exemption) x (years exempt)

oasis:entry.oasis:line: the amount that, for the final year in which the protection exemption applied, is determined as
(a) the tax that would have been payable had the exemption not applied
(b) the tax that was payable on the land that was subject to the protection covenant;
the number of taxation years during which the land was subject to the tax exemption.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The amount referred to in section 49.7 (2) (b) (i) [interest amount] of the Act is to be determined as follows:

oasis:line.in:em: interest recapture amount = (base recapture amount) x (rate)

oasis:entry.oasis:line: the amount determined in accordance with subsection (1);
the rate applicable under section 245 (1) (b) [taxes in arrear] of the Community Charter at the time at which the exemption certificate was cancelled.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Amounts received under section 49.7 of the Act may be distributed by the Minister of Finance to the trust council.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Section 397 [imposition of fees and charges] of the Local Government Act applies to the trust council in relation to the administration of Part 7.1 [Natural Area Protection Tax Exemptions] of the Islands Trust Act.

bcl:schedule.bcl:indent1: A coastal bluff ecosystem is an ecosystem described as such in the sensitive ecosystems inventory, subject to the following changes:
bcl:schedule.bcl:indent2: (a) the Site Factors are not limited to slopes of 30% or more;
(b) in the Trees & shrubs part of the Plants section, Shorepine is included.
bcl:schedule.bcl:indent1: A mature-older forest ecosystem is an ecosystem described as an older forest ecosystem in the sensitive ecosystems inventory, subject to the following changes:
bcl:schedule.bcl:indent2: (a) these are conifer-dominated forests with an average age of at least 80 years;
(b) in the Trees & shrubs part of the Plants section, Western Hemlock is included.
bcl:schedule.bcl:indent1: A riparian ecosystem is an ecosystem described as such in the sensitive ecosystems inventory.
A sparsely vegetated ecosystem is an ecosystem described as such in the sensitive ecosystems inventory.
A terrestrial herbaceous ecosystem is an ecosystem described as such in the sensitive ecosystems inventory.
A wetland ecosystem is an ecosystem described as such in the sensitive ecosystems inventory.
A woodland ecosystem is an ecosystem described as such in the sensitive ecosystems inventory, subject to the following changes:
bcl:schedule.bcl:indent2: (a) the Site Factors section is replaced with the following:

Dry, open stands of woodland that can be conifer-dominated or mixed conifer and arbutus. Woodlands may include non-forested openings, often with shallow soils and bedrock outcroppings. Garry oak woodlands are commonly in areas that comprise a mosaic of rock outcrops and shallow soils. On deep soils, the woodlands may be mixed with herbaceous meadows. In the case of aspen stands, these typically occur on moist sites;
(b) in the Trees & shrubs part of the Plants section, Western Hemlock is included and Douglas-fir trees may be more than occasional;
(c) in the Communities part of the Plants section, Douglas-fir-Lodgepole pine-Rhacomitrium is included.
